Description:
Frontiers
In Person
Clothes are the most intimate objects in our physical environment and are set to be ubiquitous in the virtual world, with the expansion of the Metaverse. They comfort, support, protect and even modify our bodies. Clothes convey style and status. They evoke subtle and strong feelings. And yet, Computer Graphics has largely treated clothing as just another type of object like a building or a tree, a 3D mesh to be simulated and rendered beautifully at high frame rates. This has often led to disappointment due to the large gap between the physical and psychological reality of clothes, and their representations in the Metaverse. This talk will take you on a journey into aspects of clothing that the field of computer graphics hasn’t usually considered, including: the biomechanics of the human body and how it interacts with clothing; the neuroscience of feelings evoked by clothing; and real-world constraints on how clothing gets made before being worn by human consumers. On the journey we will explore opportunities for computer graphics such as: making online shopping experiences in the Metaverse trustworthy; using clothing for health and wellness; and revolutionizing manufacturing to make it sustainable, on demand, and inclusive for all body types.

Contributors
Dinesh K. Pai, UBC, Vital Mechanics
Discord: join the conversation
Title: Frontiers Talk: Making Clothing Trustworthy for Humans in the Metaverse

Description:
Featured Speakers
In Person
Where does “AI” end and “we” begin? Artist and researcher Sougwen Chung’s ever-evolving work in human and machine collaboration builds upon a decade-long international journey. Starting with a simple line, the process has led to interdisciplinary insights, philosophical inquiry, and technological invention through pioneering artistic practice. Intertwining perspectives in art and science, Chung’s practice envisions alternative futures for the relationship of humans and machines. “Embracing contradictions in art and research can pave the way to a third path, inspired by tradition and the development of new hybridities,” Chung says.

Contributors
Sougwen Chung, Scilicet
Discord: join the conversation
Title: Seeing Double — Bridging Dualities With Relational Intelligence

Description:
Talk
In Person
Recording: This session WILL be recorded.
Discord: join the conversation


Green Screens, Green Pixels, and Green Shooting

Sustainability and green producing are in high demand in all sectors of creative industries. We take a closer look at two comparable productions, one using traditional offline-rendering and post-production, the other using an LED wall and ICVFX. Energy requirements, creative opportunities, and scalability are subjects of investigation and further discussion.

Contributors
Volker Helzle, Filmakademie Baden-Württemberg GmbH
Simon Spielmann, Filmakademie Baden-Württemberg GmbH
Jonas Trottnow, Filmakademie Baden-Württemberg GmbH


Open Source In-camera Visual Effects Calibration Workflow

A challenge to achieving LED panel in-camera VFX is creating a seamless integration between real and digital scenes. This integration should be valid for the camera, not the human eye. To solve this issue, we propose an open source calibration framework designed to make the best use of today’s technology.

Contributors
Carol Payne, Netflix
Francesco Luigi Giardiello, Netflix


'Comandante': Braving the Waves With Near Real-time Virtual Production Workflows

The naval feature film "Comandante" is to be shot on a water stage within a waterproof but very low-res LED volume. The near real-time workflow immediately improves the quality of the shot, seamlessly bridging in-camera VFX and post-production, allowing VFX to start on-set as soon as the director says "cut."

Contributors
Dan Ring, Foundry
Kevin Tod Haug, KTH VFX
Pierpaulo Verga, O'Groove Productions
David Stump, American Society of Cinematographers
Niall Redmond, Foundry
Dan Caffrey, Foundry
Peter Canning, High Res
Title: Virtual Production

In Person
BROUGHT TO YOU BY EPIC GAMES - UNREAL ENGINE

In this talk, Diana will provide a behind-the-scenes look at the field of special projects cinematics ⁠— which combines traditional filmmaking and virtual production to blur the boundaries between cinematics and games. The talk will analyze a number of examples created using Unreal Engine including The Matrix Awakens and other content for games and technology demonstrations to show what distinguishes them from a traditional cinematic.

Attendees will learn what new job opportunities artists can expect in the field and where special projects are headed for the future. The talk will also offer thoughts on different roles within Epic, including what jobs entail, the challenges, and which skills/attributes are most important for success.

Contributors
Diana Diriwaechter, Epic Games
Title: Educator's Day - The Art of Real-Time Special Projects

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
Metaverse is a shared virtual 3D world that is interactive, immersive, and collaborative. NVIDIA Omniverse paves the way for interconnected creativity in 3D, physically realistic, virtual worlds. In this presentation we explore the latest interactive and collaborative workflows made possible by Omniverse. We believe educators and students will help us shape the future of a world with an infinite number of connections, app to app, person to person, and classroom to classroom. We will cover how to get started with Omniverse in an educational setting Programs for Educators and other resources available through the NVIDIA Deep Learning Institute and the NVIDIA Studio Education Partner Program. Multiple hands-on labs using Omniverse are offered at SIGGRAPH in the West Building, Ballroom A/B on Monday & Tuesday August 8th& 9th.

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

Description:
Art Gallery
In Person
Art Gallery is a juried exhibition that showcases the latest innovations in digital art and welcomes artists and enthusiasts alike to a space for creative contemplation.
Discord: join the conversation


Glacier's Lament

Glaciers are sentinels of climate change. They are the most visible evidence of global warming today. This series of works embodies the stunning beauty, rapid change, fragility, destructive power, and magnificence of glaciers. At the same time, they challenge the audience with the dramatic, irreversible ecological damages from climate change.

Contributors
Jiabao Li, University of Texas at Austin, Harvard University
Cooper Galvin, University of Texas at Austin, Stanford University


Imagraph

The participants lie on their backs and shut their eyes. Two LED display boards are suspended above their heads, with optical fibers from each of the 2560 pixels extending to the surface of their eyelids. A cold-color video compensated for the blood and flesh of the eyelids is played. This project mediates between two very fundamental "attitudes": projecting the images and closing the senses.

Contributors
Goki Muramoto, The University of Tokyo


Morphogenesis I : coast, shrub, forest

This piece fuses the tools of molecular biology and artificial intelligence to help understand the complex landscapes of soil biodiversity across California ecosystems: coast, shrub, and forest. The visual is based on a microbial dataset produced by the CALeDNA program. The samples were processed for environmental DNA-metabarcoding, which allows the characterization of the community composition across regions. A variation of Neural Cellular Automata was developed to visually express the biological mechanisms of single-cell growth self-assembling into complex organisms. The form and composition are determined by the interaction of bacterial phyla in a corresponding sample. Courtesy of the State of California.

Contributors
Maru Garcia, Independent
Hye Min Cho, Independent
Maura Palacios, Independent


My Data Body

My Data Body is a collaborative, multimedia installation that include sculptures, video projection, prints and virtual reality. My Data Body brings together different forms of personal data such as medical scans, social media, biometric, banking and health data in an attempt to make visible and manipulable our many intersecting data corpuses so that in VR they can be held, inspected and dissected. In My Data Body, the medically scanned, passive, obedient, semi-transparent body becomes a data processing site that can be pulled apart, de- and re-composed or as Yuval Harari warns ‘surveilled under the skin’.

Contributors
Marilene Oliver, University of Alberta, Marilene Julie Oliver
Scott Smallwood, University of Alberta
Stephan Moore, Northwestern University.
J.R. Carpenter, Unaffiliated


Radiant Soma

Radiant Soma emphasizes the ephemerality of human movement by visualizing motion capture data with light. The installation transforms inanimate phosphorescent structures into metaphorical shamans that accept and expel spirits generated from human movement and lasers. Visitors can engage with the work on three levels: as a viewer of dance manifested through light, as a reader of embodied memory records, and in contemplation of the energies being expelled.

Contributors
Jayson Haebich, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Eugenia S. Kim, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Alvaro Cassinelli, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong


Ray

RAY provides a responsive art experience that re-interprets Rayograph (photogram) – a 20th Century cameraless image-making technique – in the perspective of Artificial Intelligent (AI) surveillance and the changing ontology of images. The system implements Image-to-Image Translation with Conditional Adversarial Networks and a computer vision system to translate human portraits into new images of Rayograph with semantic meanings, which are further developed algorithmically through visualizing in the aesthetics of light painting. RAY bridges intelligent visualization with cameraless photography Rayograph to engage audiences with an interactive poetic experience that conveys meanings.

Contributors
Weidi Zhang, Media Arts and Technology Program (MAT), University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB)


Sympathetic Wear

Taking the human back as theme, Sympathetic Wear is an artwork that brings gentle healing to the mind and body of a person on the other side of the network, employing an “expanding leaf” actuator our team developed to create the tactile sensation of soft caressing on the back of the receiver that is invisible to them on screen.

Contributors
Junichi Kanebako, Kobe Design University
Naoya Watabe, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Miki Yamamura, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Haruki Nakamura, SANNANE G.K
Keisuke Shuto, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Hiroko Uchiyama, Joshibi University of Art and Design


Three Stage Drawing Transfer

Creating a visual-mental-physical circuit between a generative adversarial network (GAN), a co-robotic arm, and a five-year-old child, this project establishes a series of translational stages between human and non-human actors. It plays with embodiment and presence: from the anonymous children who created the training images, to the co-robot realizing the GAN-generated imagery, to the human child’s active perception and response. It asks us to reconsider machine learning, creative AI, and robotic automation through a lens of human imagination, perception, and experience.

Contributors
Robert Twomey, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, UNL; Athur Clarke Center for Human Imagination, Arthur C. Clarke Center for Human Imagination, UCSD


VastWaste

VastWaste, a data-driven, projection art installation, illuminates the parallels and interplay between marine pollution and space debris. Available also in VR. VastWaste generates an everchanging Kessler Effect in conjunction with a data-driven soundtrack. Satellites spin based on the speed of marine debris. This is calculated by using ocean currents and ocean winds. The number of fragments falling into the ocean is tied to human use of satellites, symbolized by number of tweets per second. Generative music varies in each play based on collisions, number of fragments, their contact with the surface of the ocean and their descent into the ocean.

Contributors
Ozge Samanci, Northwestern University
Title: Art Gallery

Demonstrating poimo as Inflatable, Inclusive Mobility Devices with a Soft Input Interface

Poimo is a new type of electric vehicle made of inflatables. Conventional vehicles are heavy, rigid, and space-consuming. The poimo offers features of lightweight, soft, and foldable. We provide a design software system that generates custom-made poimo pattern data for each user from the intuitive input.

Demonstration of Electrical Head Actuation: Enabling Interactive Systems to Directly Manipulate Head Orientation

We demonstrate a novel interface concept where interactive systems directly manipulate the user’s head orientation. We exhibit this in two applications: (1) finding visual targets in mixed reality while the system guides their point-of-view; (2) a VR roller coaster where the user's head nods up as the ride accelerates.

Contributors
Yudai Tanaka, University of Chicago
Shan-Yuan Teng, University of Chicago
Jun Nishida, University of Chicago
Pedro Lopes, University of Chicago


Dual Robot Avatar: Real-time Multispace Experience Using Telepresence Robots and Walk Sensation Feedback Including Viewpoint Sharing for Immersive Virtual Tours

Our study attempts to operate multiple telepresence robots in remote places at the same time with presenting walk sensation feedback to the operator for an immersive, multispace experience. We used semi-autonomous mobile robots where their direction can be controlled by an operator.

Hdr Vr

We present a high dynamic range virtual reality demonstrator capable of reproducing the full range of typical indoor luminance values, from 0.05 nits to more than 16,000 nits. Demo visitors will experience this higher fidelity VR display that more fully utilizes the human eye's dynamic range.

Description:
Featured Speakers
In Person
Shading Languages and the Emergence of Programmable Graphics Systems

Shading languages were pioneered by Ken Perlin and Rob Cook, and became widely available in Pixar's RenderMan. Early graphics and imagine hardware such as the Ikonas was also programmable. Nowadays, programmable GPUs are the faster computers in the world. This talk will review their history and discuss the broader implications for computing and the future of computer graphics.


The Wild, Unexpected, Exponential Ride Through Computer Graphics

A brief tale of the early belief in the promise of computer graphics, its early support by DARPA at Utah, the depiction of the research in graphics as impractical, the incorporation of graphics in workstations, the role of the SIGGRAPH community leading to advances enabling movies, the incorporation of algorithms in GPUs, and the exponential rise of computing power in those GPUs driven by the Game Industry leading to completely unexpected results.

Contributors
Pat Hanrahan, Stanford University
Ed Catmull, Retired President of Pixar and Disney Animation

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
This session is for all attendees who value the role of design disciplines in shaping the future of graphic and interactive technologies, aiming to form a community for next generation designers. Come meet the members of the ACM SIGGRAPH Design Committee, to discuss pressing areas of interest and concern, new methods and problem spaces, as well as the increasingly important role of design in shaping the future.

Design with technology results in innovative artifacts such as smart product design (i.e. Internet of Things), wearable product design (i.e. smart glasses), fashion design (i.e. smart clothes and shoes), and architectural design and engineering (i.e. responsive buildings and structures). New types of designers are searching for a community to join, in order to learn, share, and present innovative design results, both academically and commercially.

Areas of interest include:
* Smart object design: product design, fashion, architecture, urbanism
* Centering the human: the human body, but also attributes such as pleasure, aesthetics, wellness, gender, equity, inclusion, and diversity
* Environmental issues: climate change, living creatures, and the post human
* Methodologies: design thinking, design futures/fiction, speculative design, other methods for innovation

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

Contributors
Masa Inakage, KMD, Keio University Graduate School of Media Design
Mona Kasra, University of Virginia
Joanna Berzowska, Concordia University
Makai Smith, Digiplaysty
June Kim, UNSW ART & DESIGN
Title: New Initiative: ACM SIGGRAPH Design Community

Description:
Production Session
In Person
Walt Disney Animation Studios’ “Encanto” tells the tale of an extraordinary family, the Madrigals, who live hidden in the mountains of Colombia, in a magical house, in a vibrant town, in a wondrous, charmed place called an Encanto. The magic of the Encanto has blessed every child in the family with a unique gift from super strength to the power to heal - every child except one, Mirabel. But when she discovers that the magic surrounding the Encanto is in danger, Mirabel decides that she, the only ordinary Madrigal, might just be her exceptional family’s last hope.

In this session, our filmmakers break down their collaborative process in creating the iconic song sequence, “We Don’t Talk About Bruno.” We’ll start off by discussing the work and tight focus that went into creating this large, diverse, magical family. We will discuss our approach to building characters for a musical set in Colombia, knowing they would have to move and dance in a very specific way. We will also dive deeply into the cinematography process for this sequence - discussing the theatrical inspiration and the partnerships between choreography, layout, and animation. We will also reveal why certain editing and lighting choices were made to allow viewers to experience a single-cut feel, both theatrically and musically, throughout the song.

Please join us, as we detail our collaborative filmmaking process.

DON'T MISS!
We Don’t Talk About Bruno - An Encanto Musical Sequence Unveiled
Monday, 8 August, 5:15-6:15 pm
Located outside Ballroom C/D

Practical Course on Computing Derivatives in Code

Course
Virtual
Derivatives occur frequently in many applications, including simulation, optimization, and machine learning. The purpose of this course is to show how to implement derivatives in code. This course provides practical strategies and techniques for planning, computing, testing, debugging, and optimizing routines for computing first and second derivatives of real-world routines.

Evidence-based Science Communication and Cinematic Scientific Visualization

Course

Description:
Talk
In Person

Discord: join the conversation


On Fairness in Face Albedo Estimation

The goal of this talk is to raise awareness in the graphics community of the problem of racial bias in face albedo estimation. We discuss potential causes and show how these problems can be ameliorated by recent advances, improving fairness in albedo estimation.

Contributors
Haiwen Feng, Max Planck Institue for Intelligent Systems
Timo Bolkart, Max Planck Institue for Intelligent Systems
Joachim Tesch, Max Planck Institue for Intelligent Systems
Michael Black, Max Planck Institue for Intelligent Systems
Victoria Abrevaya, Max Planck Institue for Intelligent Systems


Advances in Spatial Hashing: A Pragmatic Approach towards Robust Real-time Light Transport Simulation

Spatial hashing is a battle-tested technique for efficient storage of sparse spatial data. We extend this approach to glossy reflections using world-space temporal filtering. We also optimize the hash key generation for better cache coherence and aliasing reduction. Finally, we increase the sampling quality, in particular using visibility-aware environment sampling.

Contributors
Pascal Gautron, NVIDIA


Practical Multiple-scattering Sheen Using Linearly Transformed Cosines

We introduce a new volumetric sheen BRDF that approximates scattering observed in surfaces covered with normally oriented fibers. The new model allows a more realistic cloth appearance and can approximate a dusty appearance. The BRDF is implemented using a linearly transformed cosine (LTC) lobe fitted to a volumetric scattering layer.

Contributors
Tizian Zeltner, EPFL, NVIDIA
Brent Burley, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Matt Jen-Yuan Chiang, Walt Disney Animation Studios, Meta Reality Labs


Countering Racial Bias in Computer Graphics Research

Current computer graphics research practices contain racial biases that have resulted in investigations into "skin" and "hair" that focus on the hegemonic visual features of Europeans and East Asians. To broaden our research horizons, we present technical proposals that aim to stimulate further discussion and pose novel, open research problems.

Contributors
Theodore Kim, Yale University
Holly Rushmeier, Yale University
Julie Dorsey, Yale University
Derek Nowrouzezahrai, McGill University
Raqi Syed, Victoria University of Wellington
Wojciech Jarosz, Dartmouth College
A.M. Darke, University of California Santa Cruz
Title: Surface Rendering and Lighting

The metaverse is the buzzword of the day. But is it really the beginning? Or is it already here? This event positions current Metaverse precursors to initiate a dialogue about what is already possible. The aim is to foster discussion about how interactive immersive experience will change the way that we learn, work, socialize, and play. A short set of panelist talks will set the stage. Description:
Frontiers
In Person
The possibility of touching the metaverse has captured not only the interest of researchers & industry but even the attention of consumers. However, haptics is passing through a critical challenge that graphics just went through. Not only do we need to see virtual objects, but also physical objects. This is what happened as graphics moved from virtual reality (VR) to augmented reality (AR). Yet, haptics is still at its infancy to explore this phase transition. For instance, gloves for VR come at a substantial cost, since areas of the hand with which we often interact with physical objects are obstructed, preventing us from feeling naturally occurring touch sensations or to perform important manual tasks in the Metaverse. In this session, we will explore how Haptics can help make experiences in the Metaverse more immersive.

Keynotes by Pedro Lopes (Prof. at the University of Chicago) and Nicholas Colonnese (Research Science Manager at Meta Reality Labs).

Learn more about the speakers at:
Pedro Lopes: https://lab.plopes.org/
Nicholas Colonnese: https://www.ncolonnese.com/

Contributors
Pedro Lopes, University of Chicago
Nicholas Colonnese, Facebook Reality Labs

Description:
Birds of a Feather
Virtual
Vulkan is a cross-platform industry standard enabling developers to target, with the same graphics API, a heterogeneous ecosystem.

However, being cross-platform is not enough from a Vulkan developer's perspective. The application will only target a domain of relevance to the Vulkan ecosystem, a domain that can be formalized with a Vulkan Profile, a way to express Vulkan capabilities requirements.

In this presentation, we will discuss the tools shipping with the Vulkan SDK to simplify Vulkan application development thanks to Vulkan Profiles.

Contributors
Christophe Riccio, LunarG, Inc.

Computer graphics is one of the most challenging computer science problems of our time. 'Encanto' — Let's Talk About Bruno's Visions

In Walt Disney Animation Studios’ “Encanto,” Mirabel discovers remnants of her Uncle Bruno's visions. Developing the look and lighting for these shards required close collaboration between multiple departments to create a unique holographic effect. This talk covers the creative approaches and collaborative processes that brought this effect to the screen.

Contributors
Corey Butler, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Brent Burley, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Wei-Feng Wayne Huang, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Yining Karl Li, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Benjamin Min Huang, Walt Disney Animation Studios


Fracture-aware Tessellation of Subdivision Surfaces

We introduce a new tessellation algorithm for production rendering of fractured subdivision surfaces. Our method produces higher quality results with less distortion than previous approaches, enables a more efficient fracture pipeline, and was key to animating the destruction of Casa Madrigal in Disney Animation’s "Encanto."

Contributors
Brent Burley, Walt Disney Animation Studios
Francisco Rodriguez, Walt Disney Animation Studios


The New York Times: Spatial Storytelling and Scientific Data Visualization

With misinformation spreading as quickly as the coronavirus itself, we saw an urgent need to clearly illustrate complicated scientific concepts to help readers assess risk and stay safe. We'll dive into the reporting, design, and production of three recently published pieces that visualized scientific information in 3D.

Contributors
Karthik Patanjali, The New York Times
Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, The New York Times
Noah Pisner, The New York Times
Nick Bartzokas, The New York Times

Description:
Birds of a Feather
Virtual
Digital twins can be used to replicate in-person learning opportunities in a virtual environment. Educators often tightly script these experiences as case studies. Others would prefer including algorithms for flexibility and fidelity. Most teams won’t have expertise in all the domains required to build digital twins such as these. This BoF session will provide an opportunity for educators to meet and discuss with researchers and industry. Discussion topics will include best practices, learning outcomes, application design, and application development.

Contributors
Jason Whitley, NCSU Biomanufacturing Training Education Center, NCSU College of Art + Design
Discord: join the conversation
Recording: This session WILL be recorded.
Title: Digital twins for educators

Become a developer for the next wave of physically accurate 3D virtual worlds and learn to build on NVIDIA Omniverse. In this session you’ll build your own custom scene manipulator tools in Omniverse using a few lines of Python code. See how you can build advanced tools on the modular, easily extensible Omniverse platform and learn from the Omniverse developer ecosystem team how you can extend and enhance the 3D tools you know and love today.

Contributors
Paul Cutsinger, NVIDIA
Damien Fagnou, NVIDIA
Justin Kovac, NVIDIA

Description:
Art Gallery
In Person
Art Gallery is a juried exhibition that showcases the latest innovations in digital art and welcomes artists and enthusiasts alike to a space for creative contemplation.
Discord: join the conversation


Glacier's Lament

Glaciers are sentinels of climate change. They are the most visible evidence of global warming today. This series of works embodies the stunning beauty, rapid change, fragility, destructive power, and magnificence of glaciers. At the same time, they challenge the audience with the dramatic, irreversible ecological damages from climate change.

Contributors
Jiabao Li, University of Texas at Austin, Harvard University
Cooper Galvin, University of Texas at Austin, Stanford University


Imagraph

The participants lie on their backs and shut their eyes. Two LED display boards are suspended above their heads, with optical fibers from each of the 2560 pixels extending to the surface of their eyelids. A cold-color video compensated for the blood and flesh of the eyelids is played. This project mediates between two very fundamental "attitudes": projecting the images and closing the senses.

Contributors
Goki Muramoto, The University of Tokyo


Morphogenesis I : coast, shrub, forest

This piece fuses the tools of molecular biology and artificial intelligence to help understand the complex landscapes of soil biodiversity across California ecosystems: coast, shrub, and forest. The visual is based on a microbial dataset produced by the CALeDNA program. The samples were processed for environmental DNA-metabarcoding, which allows the characterization of the community composition across regions. A variation of Neural Cellular Automata was developed to visually express the biological mechanisms of single-cell growth self-assembling into complex organisms. The form and composition are determined by the interaction of bacterial phyla in a corresponding sample. Courtesy of the State of California.

Contributors
Maru Garcia, Independent
Hye Min Cho, Independent
Maura Palacios, Independent


My Data Body

My Data Body is a collaborative, multimedia installation that include sculptures, video projection, prints and virtual reality. My Data Body brings together different forms of personal data such as medical scans, social media, biometric, banking and health data in an attempt to make visible and manipulable our many intersecting data corpuses so that in VR they can be held, inspected and dissected. In My Data Body, the medically scanned, passive, obedient, semi-transparent body becomes a data processing site that can be pulled apart, de- and re-composed or as Yuval Harari warns ‘surveilled under the skin’.

Contributors
Marilene Oliver, University of Alberta, Marilene Julie Oliver
Scott Smallwood, University of Alberta
Stephan Moore, Northwestern University.
J.R. Carpenter, Unaffiliated


Radiant Soma

Radiant Soma emphasizes the ephemerality of human movement by visualizing motion capture data with light. The installation transforms inanimate phosphorescent structures into metaphorical shamans that accept and expel spirits generated from human movement and lasers. Visitors can engage with the work on three levels: as a viewer of dance manifested through light, as a reader of embodied memory records, and in contemplation of the energies being expelled.

Contributors
Jayson Haebich, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Eugenia S. Kim, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Alvaro Cassinelli, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong


Ray

RAY provides a responsive art experience that re-interprets Rayograph (photogram) – a 20th Century cameraless image-making technique – in the perspective of Artificial Intelligent (AI) surveillance and the changing ontology of images. The system implements Image-to-Image Translation with Conditional Adversarial Networks and a computer vision system to translate human portraits into new images of Rayograph with semantic meanings, which are further developed algorithmically through visualizing in the aesthetics of light painting. RAY bridges intelligent visualization with cameraless photography Rayograph to engage audiences with an interactive poetic experience that conveys meanings.

Contributors
Weidi Zhang, Media Arts and Technology Program (MAT), University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB)


Sympathetic Wear

Taking the human back as theme, Sympathetic Wear is an artwork that brings gentle healing to the mind and body of a person on the other side of the network, employing an “expanding leaf” actuator our team developed to create the tactile sensation of soft caressing on the back of the receiver that is invisible to them on screen.

Contributors
Junichi Kanebako, Kobe Design University
Naoya Watabe, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Miki Yamamura, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Haruki Nakamura, SANNANE G.K
Keisuke Shuto, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Hiroko Uchiyama, Joshibi University of Art and Design


Three Stage Drawing Transfer

Creating a visual-mental-physical circuit between a generative adversarial network (GAN), a co-robotic arm, and a five-year-old child, this project establishes a series of translational stages between human and non-human actors. It plays with embodiment and presence: from the anonymous children who created the training images, to the co-robot realizing the GAN-generated imagery, to the human child’s active perception and response. It asks us to reconsider machine learning, creative AI, and robotic automation through a lens of human imagination, perception, and experience.

Contributors
Robert Twomey, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, UNL; Athur Clarke Center for Human Imagination, Arthur C. Clarke Center for Human Imagination, UCSD


VastWaste

VastWaste, a data-driven, projection art installation, illuminates the parallels and interplay between marine pollution and space debris. Available also in VR. VastWaste generates an everchanging Kessler Effect in conjunction with a data-driven soundtrack. Satellites spin based on the speed of marine debris. This is calculated by using ocean currents and ocean winds. The number of fragments falling into the ocean is tied to human use of satellites, symbolized by number of tweets per second. Generative music varies in each play based on collisions, number of fragments, their contact with the surface of the ocean and their descent into the ocean.

Contributors
Ozge Samanci, Northwestern University

Demonstrating poimo as Inflatable, Inclusive Mobility Devices with a Soft Input Interface

Poimo is a new type of electric vehicle made of inflatables. Conventional vehicles are heavy, rigid, and space-consuming. The poimo offers features of lightweight, soft, and foldable. We provide a design software system that generates custom-made poimo pattern data for each user from the intuitive input.

Demonstration of Electrical Head Actuation: Enabling Interactive Systems to Directly Manipulate Head Orientation

We demonstrate a novel interface concept where interactive systems directly manipulate the user’s head orientation. We exhibit this in two applications: (1) finding visual targets in mixed reality while the system guides their point-of-view; (2) a VR roller coaster where the user's head nods up as the ride accelerates.

Contributors
Yudai Tanaka, University of Chicago
Shan-Yuan Teng, University of Chicago
Jun Nishida, University of Chicago
Pedro Lopes, University of Chicago


Dual Robot Avatar: Real-time Multispace Experience Using Telepresence Robots and Walk Sensation Feedback Including Viewpoint Sharing for Immersive Virtual Tours

Our study attempts to operate multiple telepresence robots in remote places at the same time with presenting walk sensation feedback to the operator for an immersive, multispace experience. We used semi-autonomous mobile robots where their direction can be controlled by an operator.

Hdr Vr

We present a high dynamic range virtual reality demonstrator capable of reproducing the full range of typical indoor luminance values, from 0.05 nits to more than 16,000 nits. Demo visitors will experience this higher fidelity VR display that more fully utilizes the human eye's dynamic range.

Contributors
Nathan Matsuda, Reality Labs Research, Meta
Yang Zhao, Reality Labs Research, Meta

ImageFlowing-Enhance Emotional Expression by Reproducing the Vital Signs of the Photographer

ImageFlowing is a "living" photograph that reproduces the biometric signs of the photographer. Viewers can feel how the photographer felt through the photographer’s breathing, heartbeats, and skin temperature. We extend a 2D picture into a multi-modal experience, aiming at creating a tighter emotional link between the viewer and the photographer.

Meta Avatar Robot Cafe: Linking Physical and Virtual Cybernetic Avatars to Provide Physical Augmentation for People with Disabilities

Meta avatar robot cafe is a cafe that fuses cyberspace and physical space to create new encounters with people. We create a place where people with disabilities who have difficulty going out can freely switch between their physical bodies and virtual bodies, and communicate their presence and warmth to each other.

Rapid Design of Articulated Objects: An Interactive Showcase

We present a novel 3D sketching system for rapidly designing articulated 3D concepts with a small set of coherent pen and multi-touch gestures. Our system bridges the gap between 2D sketching and 3D modeling and is generally applicable in film, animation, game, and product design.

Contributors
Joon Hyub Lee, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
Hanbit Kim, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
Seok-Hyung Bae, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)


ReQTable: Square Tabletop Display That Provides Dual-sided Mid-air Images to Each of 4 Users

We propose “ReQTable,” an optical system displaying dual-sided mid-air images to each of four users. However, the actual dual SMAs also make unwanted light, called stray light. In this study, we propose the method to suppress the light by using linear polarizer and VCFs.

Contributors
Mizuki Takenawa, The University of Tokyo
Tomoyo Kikuchi, The University of Tokyo
Yuchi Yahagi, The University of Tokyo
Shogo Fukushima, The University of Tokyo

Sense of Embodiment Inducement for People With Reduced Lower-body Mobility and Sensations With Partial-visuomotor Stimulation

We demonstrate an upper-body, motion-tracking-based, partial-visuomotor technique to induce sense of embodiment (SoE) for people with reduced lower-body mobility and sensation (PRLMS) patients.

ThermoBlinds: Non-contact, Highly Responsive Thermal Feedback for Thermal Interaction

We present ThermoBlinds, a non-contact, highly responsive thermal feedback device. It provides highly responsive thermal feedback by rapidly adjusting infrared irradiance with a shutter mechanism. The applications include visual media experience with thermal feedback, remote communication support with gaze-based thermal feedback, and behavior change with activity-based thermal feedback.

​​Waving Blanket: Dynamic Liquid Distribution for Multiple Tactile Feedback Using Rewirable Piping System

We present Waving Blanket, a dynamic liquid distribution system for multiple tactile feedback, utilizing a water pump and air valve to transmit and allocate the liquid in the pipe, and a relaxation application called "Water Forest" with our haptic system to show the possibility by combining visual-auditory feedback.

WonderScope: Practical Near-surface AR Device for Museum Exhibits

We propose a practical near-surface AR device for museum exhibits called WonderScope, a peripheral device for mobiles. With a small RFID tag, it enables an experience like seeing through or magnifying the surface of exhibits. It performs on various materials of surfaces, regardless of the lighting environment.

Immersive technologies advance the ways we create, communicate, learn, and play. Experience awe-inspiring breakthroughs in VR, AR, and MR at SIGGRAPH.

A Clever Label

A Clever Label is a multi-sensory interactive VR experience, using a novel real-time spatial data visualization mechanic to present interconnected data. The in-VR host provides a short introduction then invites users to explore the data. This is an artistic project, but the mechanic also supports dataviz as a productivity tool.

Contributors
Michela Ledwidge, Mod


Becoming: An Interactive Musical Journey in VR

Becoming is an operatic VR piece based on a Persian poem by Mowlana Rumi. The user can interact with the environment and the music. Two audience members can be connected through the network and interact with each other via haptic and spatialization effects.

Contributors
Shahrokh Yadegari, Sonic Arts Research and Development/Qualcomm Institute, UC San Diego

Delirious Departures

Delirious Departures is a nomadic untethered VR experience, created by artists Eric Joris and Isjtar as part of CREW. Combining socially intelligent avatars, a live actor, and awe-inspiring environments, Delirious Departures diffuses technology developed within the PRESENT EU Horizon 2020 research project.

Contributors
Isjtar Vandebroeck, CREW
Eric Joris, CREW


Fruit Golf: An Asymmetrical Shared Space VR/Mobile Experience

Fruit Golf is an asymmetric multiplayer game that integrates VR and mobile devices to offer a shared social experience.

Shane Nilsson, Coal Car Studio

Glasshouse

Glasshouse is a dance for VR experience in three parts. A near future biosphere where plant and insect life thrive in an ecosystem of integrated biotechnology. Maintained by intuitive glasshouse keepers who farm water and light, biotech agriculture and drone insects work in synergy with ancient flora and heirloom edibles.

Sarah Neville, Deakin University/ Coventry University, University of South Australia
Matthew Thomas, Central Queensland University, Westwood Thomas Associates
Alex DeGaris, University of South Australia

Hummingbird: A Collaborative Live Theater and Virtual Reality Adventure

Hummingbird is a modern, innovative performance merging live theater and interactive virtual reality, immersing the audience in the performance and giving them agency and control over the action. Hummingbird’s story celebrates courage and coming of age through the eyes of a gutsy teen who must survive dangerous new technology.

HyperJumping in Virtual Vancouver: Combating Motion Sickness by Merging Teleporting and Continuous VR Locomotion in an Embodied Hands-free VR Flying Paradigm

Motion sickness, unintuitive navigation, and limited agency are critical issues in VR/XR impeding widespread adoption and enjoyable user experiences. To tackle these challenges, we present HyperJump, a novel VR interface merging advantages of continuous locomotion and teleportation/dashing into one seamless, hands-free, and easily learnable interface for flying and ground-based locomotion.

Immersive Real World through Deep Billboards

We propose Deep Billboard Objects, which reproduces pseudo-3D objects in a virtual world based on 2D generative deep learning methods, and also enables interaction with the objects. Our proposed system allows for the use of highly accurate deep generative models without degradation, and even in virtual worlds on low-end devices.

Journal of My Journey: Seamless Interaction in Virtuality and Reality With Digital Fabrication and Sensory Feedback

Journal of My Journey is a work that explores the possibilities of integrating seamless interactions in virtuality and reality. We let the choices that the users make in the virtual world be output to the real world, thus enhancing the the connection between the reality and the virtual world.

Living with Smell Dysfunction: A Multi-sensory VR Experience

“Living with Smell Dysfunction” is an immersive multi-sensory VR experience exploring the everyday struggles of those with invisible disabilities, such as smell dysfunction.

Contributors
Yuting Wang, BroadAR, University of California Berkeley
Ziqing Li, BroadAR, New York University


Madrid Noir

Madrid Noir is an interactive VR experience that is staged as an immersive theater production inspired by film noir. In the 1930s in a Madrid lost to time, we join Lola, a disenchanted young woman who arrives in Madrid to empty her estranged uncle’s apartment after he is declared dead.

Contributors
James Castillo, No Ghost
Antoine Cayrol, Atlas V
Luke Gibbard, No Ghost

Mixed Reality Collaboration for Complementary Working Styles

Our project combines immersive VR, multitouch AR, real-time volumetric capture, robotically actuated tangible interfaces at multiple scales, spatial audio, and live coding in service of a human-centric way of collaborating. Participants bring their own unique talents and preferences to tackle complex problems together in a shared, mixed-reality world.

Nachtalb: A Multisensory Neurofeedback VR Interface

Nachtalb is a multi-sensory neurofeedback VR interface that allows the user's brain to interact with itself. It appears as a virtual reality installation.

XR Design Framework

Take a peek at XR Design Framework, Unity's internal multi-user XR collaboration tool. XR Design Frameworkprovides a delightful interface to navigate and manipulate freeform and guided experiences. Tools and technology are provided on top for voice chat, avatars, annotations, and sharing.

Star-Stuff: A Way for the Universe to Know Itself

Star-Stuff is a multi-user immersive experience that transforms immersants’ bodies into constellations surrounded by myriad interactive orbiting stars whose lifetimes unfold before their eyes. This surreal VR artwork brings two immersants together remotely or in-person to give a new perspective on themselves, humanity, and the universe.

Contributors
John Desnoyers-Stewart, Simon Fraser University


Walking a Turtle

In “Walking a Turtle," players take a walk with a tortoise, based upon Walter Benjamin’s account of Parisian flâneurs. “Around 1840, it was briefly fashionable to take turtles for a walk in the arcades.” Part game, part quantified-self wellness tracker, “Walking” is a farcical tool for resisting the attention economy.

Contributors
Jeremy Rotsztain, Studio Mantissa
Alice Rotsztain, Studio Mantissa

Making 'Encanto' With USD: Rebuilding a Production Pipeline Working From Home

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
Part 2: Artists, scientists, technologists, and social practitioners have the power to critically respond to the issues facing our planet. By engaging in practices and producing artwork that seek to critically respond to the issues facing the natural world, these artists help us re-imagine a better future. In January 2022, the ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community launched an online exhibition that showcased creative works that investigated, questioned, and proposed critical action to reestablish a sustainable and balanced relationship with The Earth, Our Home (https://earth-our-home.siggraph.org/). The works range from scientific visualization, AI investigations, virtual and augmented experiences, and aesthetic encounters. During the online exhibition opening, the artists gave lightning talks at a SPARKS session. At this ACM SIGGRAPH Village presentation, highlights from the SPARKS talks from half of the artists in the exhibition will be shown. In addition, Mona Kasra and Julieta Aguilera will be discussing their artworks as well as the environmental issues they addressed. Part 1 of The Earth, Our Home - Art, Technology, and Critical Action Online Exhibition is available in the ACM SIGGRAPH Village online sessions and will focus on the other 10 artworks in the show.

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

Contributors
Bonnie Mitchell, ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community, Bowling Green State University
Janice Searleman, ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community, Clarkson University
Title: Digital Arts: The Earth, Our Home - Art, Technology, and Critical Action Online Exhibition, Part 2

Description:
Frontiers
In Person
Linear perspective is a simple and elegant method of representing 3D space on a 2D plane. It was discovered by artists and architects in the fifteenth century and now underpins nearly all our imaging technologies, from cameras to computer graphics engines. Yet few people are aware of its limitations and the fact that artists have rarely used it because of them, or that several other nonlinear methods exist that can do a better job in conveying subjective visual experience. These other methods have a surprisingly rich history in art and mathematics and are increasingly relevant to those developing new forms of 3D rendering and computational photography. How to computationally model and apply these methods remains an important open research problem.

The workshop will explore this area of frontier research in depth and from several disciplinary angles and aims to foster research between computer graphics, art, and visual perception. A panel of experts from different fields will discuss various forms of artistically-inspired perspectives, the relationship between these perspectives and the human visual system, and the impact they are having on computer graphics and computational photography. An optional drawing exercise will help participants appreciate critical features of human visual experience and better understand some of the ideas that will be presented.

Contributors
Aaron Hertzmann, Adobe Research
Jan J. Koenderink, KU Leuven, Utrecht University
Robert Pepperell, Cardiff University
Discord: join the conversation
Title: Frontiers Workshop: Beyond Linear Perspective: Art, Human Vision, and Computer Graphics

Desktop-based High-quality Facial Capture for Everyone

We present two novel desktop-based systems for high-quality facial capture including geometry and facial appearance. The proposed acquisition systems are highly practical and scalable, consisting purely of commodity components. Both setups consist of a set of displays for controlled illumination for reflectance capture, in conjunction multiview acquisition of facial geometry.

Contributors
Alexandros Lattas, Imperial College London

High-fidelity Facial Reconstruction From a Single Photo Using Photo-realistic Rendering

We propose a fast automated method for realistic 3D face reconstruction from a single photo. The method optimally combines a convolutional neural network trained exclusively from synthetic data with landmark-based facial morphing.

For the ABBA: Voyage concert experience, Industrial Light & Magic was tasked with digitally time traveling the iconic band's members back to their prime-time appearances. For the duration of this fully computer-graphics-generated concert, four continuous photo-real digital human facial performances had to be synthesized.

Advances for Digital Humans in VFX Production at Goodbye Kansas Studios

His presentation will be in person at 6 p.m. on Tuesday, August 9, in the McKenzie Ballroom at the Fairmont Waterfront Hotel, as the SIGGRAPH Pioneers also celebrate returning to the traditional Pioneers Reception format. All Pioneers members are welcome to attend.

Description:
Frontiers
In Person
Can AI algorithms make art, and be considered artists? Within the past decade, the growth of new neural network algorithms has enabled exciting new artforms with considerable public interest, including DeepDream, GANs, VAEs, and diffusion models like DALL-E and Imagen. These tools raise recurring questions about their status as creators and their effect on the arts. In this talk, I will discuss how these developments parallel the development of previous artistic technologies, like oil paint, photography, and traditional computer graphics. I argue that art is a social phenomenon, and discuss possible—but very unlikely—scenarios for when these algorithms could someday be considered artists.

Contributors
Aaron Hertzmann, Adobe Research

Title: Frontiers Talk: Art in the Age of AI: Can Computers Create Art?

Description:
Featured Speakers
In Person
A world constrained by time and distance has come to an end. Join Burkhard Boeckem, Chief Technology Officer at Hexagon AB as he unveils a new category of digital reality technologies that fundamentally change how we think about worldbuilding, design, and production. Burkhard’s passion is the democratization of digital realities, which led to Hexagon’s development of the Leica BLK line of laser scanners, the launch of HxDR, a powerful visualization and collaboration platform, and recently led to the acquisition of Immersal, an AR technology for spatial mapping and anchoring. You’re invited to enter into the advanced world where together we can create a one-to-one digital map of almost unimaginable scope—every place, every object, every process—autonomous, connected, and in real time. Discover the massive potential digital realities hold for worldbuilding, visualization, and immersive storytelling—from VFX to AEC, from metaverse to virtual production—in a world where your ideas know no constraints.

Contributors
Burkhard Boeckem, Hexagon AB

Description:
Frontiers
In Person
Advances in augmented and virtual reality have paved the way for a new type of user interface that can connect users remotely via spatial interactions: the metaverse.

However, to fully unlock the potential of the metaverse several challenges need to be solved. In this workshop we take a deep dive, with the help of our expert panelists, into some of these roadblocks, including: (1) integrating haptic sensations in the metaverse (Prof. Pedro Lopes & Shan-Yuan Teng); (2) integrating gaze and attention in user interfaces for metaverse (Yudai Tanaka & Prof. Mark Billinghurst); and (3) accelerating the prototyping of metaverse experiences (Prof. Michael Nebeling).

In this workshop, you will have a chance to learn more about these topics, share your experiences, connect with experts in the field, and network opportunities to explore these topics and other metaverse-related ideas with academics and industry. There is no required background for this workshop except a deep interest in VR/AR/haptics/graphics and the metaverse.

Contributors
Pedro Lopes, University of Chicago
Michael Nebeling, University of Michigan
Shan-Yuan Teng, University of Chicago
Mark Billinghurst, Empathic Computing Lab, The University of Auckland
Yudai Tanaka, University of Chicago
Discord: join the conversation
Title: Frontiers Workshop: Challenges to Unlock the Metaverse: Haptics, Gaze, Prototyping tools & more!

Art Gallery
In Person
Art Gallery is a juried exhibition that showcases the latest innovations in digital art and welcomes artists and enthusiasts alike to a space for creative contemplation.
Discord: join the conversation


Glacier's Lament

Glaciers are sentinels of climate change. They are the most visible evidence of global warming today. This series of works embodies the stunning beauty, rapid change, fragility, destructive power, and magnificence of glaciers. At the same time, they challenge the audience with the dramatic, irreversible ecological damages from climate change.

Contributors
Jiabao Li, University of Texas at Austin, Harvard University
Cooper Galvin, University of Texas at Austin, Stanford University


Imagraph

The participants lie on their backs and shut their eyes. Two LED display boards are suspended above their heads, with optical fibers from each of the 2560 pixels extending to the surface of their eyelids. A cold-color video compensated for the blood and flesh of the eyelids is played. This project mediates between two very fundamental "attitudes": projecting the images and closing the senses.

Contributors
Goki Muramoto, The University of Tokyo


Morphogenesis I : coast, shrub, forest

This piece fuses the tools of molecular biology and artificial intelligence to help understand the complex landscapes of soil biodiversity across California ecosystems: coast, shrub, and forest. The visual is based on a microbial dataset produced by the CALeDNA program. The samples were processed for environmental DNA-metabarcoding, which allows the characterization of the community composition across regions. A variation of Neural Cellular Automata was developed to visually express the biological mechanisms of single-cell growth self-assembling into complex organisms. The form and composition are determined by the interaction of bacterial phyla in a corresponding sample. Courtesy of the State of California.

Contributors
Maru Garcia, Independent
Hye Min Cho, Independent
Maura Palacios, Independent


My Data Body

My Data Body is a collaborative, multimedia installation that include sculptures, video projection, prints and virtual reality. My Data Body brings together different forms of personal data such as medical scans, social media, biometric, banking and health data in an attempt to make visible and manipulable our many intersecting data corpuses so that in VR they can be held, inspected and dissected. In My Data Body, the medically scanned, passive, obedient, semi-transparent body becomes a data processing site that can be pulled apart, de- and re-composed or as Yuval Harari warns ‘surveilled under the skin’.

Contributors
Marilene Oliver, University of Alberta, Marilene Julie Oliver
Scott Smallwood, University of Alberta
Stephan Moore, Northwestern University.
J.R. Carpenter, Unaffiliated


Radiant Soma

Radiant Soma emphasizes the ephemerality of human movement by visualizing motion capture data with light. The installation transforms inanimate phosphorescent structures into metaphorical shamans that accept and expel spirits generated from human movement and lasers. Visitors can engage with the work on three levels: as a viewer of dance manifested through light, as a reader of embodied memory records, and in contemplation of the energies being expelled.

Contributors
Jayson Haebich, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Eugenia S. Kim, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong
Alvaro Cassinelli, Augmented Materiality Lab, School of Creative Media, City University of Hong Kong


Ray

RAY provides a responsive art experience that re-interprets Rayograph (photogram) – a 20th Century cameraless image-making technique – in the perspective of Artificial Intelligent (AI) surveillance and the changing ontology of images. The system implements Image-to-Image Translation with Conditional Adversarial Networks and a computer vision system to translate human portraits into new images of Rayograph with semantic meanings, which are further developed algorithmically through visualizing in the aesthetics of light painting. RAY bridges intelligent visualization with cameraless photography Rayograph to engage audiences with an interactive poetic experience that conveys meanings.

Contributors
Weidi Zhang, Media Arts and Technology Program (MAT), University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB)


Sympathetic Wear

Taking the human back as theme, Sympathetic Wear is an artwork that brings gentle healing to the mind and body of a person on the other side of the network, employing an “expanding leaf” actuator our team developed to create the tactile sensation of soft caressing on the back of the receiver that is invisible to them on screen.

Contributors
Junichi Kanebako, Kobe Design University
Naoya Watabe, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Miki Yamamura, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Haruki Nakamura, SANNANE G.K
Keisuke Shuto, Joshibi University of Art and Design
Hiroko Uchiyama, Joshibi University of Art and Design


Three Stage Drawing Transfer

Creating a visual-mental-physical circuit between a generative adversarial network (GAN), a co-robotic arm, and a five-year-old child, this project establishes a series of translational stages between human and non-human actors. It plays with embodiment and presence: from the anonymous children who created the training images, to the co-robot realizing the GAN-generated imagery, to the human child’s active perception and response. It asks us to reconsider machine learning, creative AI, and robotic automation through a lens of human imagination, perception, and experience.

Contributors
Robert Twomey, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, UNL; Athur Clarke Center for Human Imagination, Arthur C. Clarke Center for Human Imagination, UCSD


VastWaste

VastWaste, a data-driven, projection art installation, illuminates the parallels and interplay between marine pollution and space debris. Available also in VR. VastWaste generates an everchanging Kessler Effect in conjunction with a data-driven soundtrack. Satellites spin based on the speed of marine debris. This is calculated by using ocean currents and ocean winds. The number of fragments falling into the ocean is tied to human use of satellites, symbolized by number of tweets per second. Generative music varies in each play based on collisions, number of fragments, their contact with the surface of the ocean and their descent into the ocean.

Contributors
Ozge Samanci, Northwestern University
Title: Art Gallery

ImageFlowing-Enhance Emotional Expression by Reproducing the Vital Signs of the Photographer

ImageFlowing is a "living" photograph that reproduces the biometric signs of the photographer. Viewers can feel how the photographer felt through the photographer’s breathing, heartbeats, and skin temperature. We extend a 2D picture into a multi-modal experience, aiming at creating a tighter emotional link between the viewer and the photographer.

Meta Avatar Robot Cafe: Linking Physical and Virtual Cybernetic Avatars to Provide Physical Augmentation for People with Disabilities

Meta avatar robot cafe is a cafe that fuses cyberspace and physical space to create new encounters with people. We create a place where people with disabilities who have difficulty going out can freely switch between their physical bodies and virtual bodies, and communicate their presence and warmth to each other.

Rapid Design of Articulated Objects: An Interactive Showcase

We present a novel 3D sketching system for rapidly designing articulated 3D concepts with a small set of coherent pen and multi-touch gestures. Our system bridges the gap between 2D sketching and 3D modeling and is generally applicable in film, animation, game, and product design.

ReQTable: Square Tabletop Display That Provides Dual-sided Mid-air Images to Each of 4 Users

We propose “ReQTable,” an optical system displaying dual-sided mid-air images to each of four users. However, the actual dual SMAs also make unwanted light, called stray light. In this study, we propose the method to suppress the light by using linear polarizer and VCFs.

We demonstrate an upper-body, motion-tracking-based, partial-visuomotor technique to induce sense of embodiment (SoE) for people with reduced lower-body mobility and sensation (PRLMS) patients.

ThermoBlinds: Non-contact, Highly Responsive Thermal Feedback for Thermal Interaction

We present ThermoBlinds, a non-contact, highly responsive thermal feedback device. It provides highly responsive thermal feedback by rapidly adjusting infrared irradiance with a shutter mechanism. The applications include visual media experience with thermal feedback, remote communication support with gaze-based thermal feedback, and behavior change with activity-based thermal feedback.

We propose a practical near-surface AR device for museum exhibits called WonderScope, a peripheral device for mobiles. Becoming: An Interactive Musical Journey in VR

Becoming is an operatic VR piece based on a Persian poem by Mowlana Rumi. The user can interact with the environment and the music. Two audience members can be connected through the network and interact with each other via haptic and spatialization effects.

Accelerating Facial Motion Capture With Video-driven Animation Transfer

We present a hybrid facial capture pipeline that combines a regression-based, video-driven transfer technique, under partially controlled conditions, with a more robust, but slower, marker-based tracking approach. We thus achieve an overall pipeline that, without loss of quality, is faster and has less user intervention.

Contributors
Jose Serra, Digital Domain
Mark Williams, Digital Domain
Lucio Moser, Digital Domain


Creating Life-like Autonomous Agents for Real-time Interactive Installations

This talk describes the implementation of a complex virtual ecosystem of autonomous agents for the purpose of an art installation. These autonomous agents are given their own sensoriums, motivations, behaviors, and personalities according to the rules of an artificial life simulation, allowing them to interact with audiences in real time.

Contributors
Nathan Lachenmyer, Sitara Systems
Sadiya Akasha, Sitara Systems


Training a Deep Remastering Model

One option for video remastering is to rescan film reels with modern devices. However, original film reels can be damaged or missing, and the content is only available in the broadcast version. We present a deep learning solution, that leverages available film segments, to bring broadcast versions to high-quality levels.

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
The mission of the ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Committee is to foster year-round engagement and dialogue within the digital, electronic, computational, and media arts. Our goal is to promote collaboration between artists and the larger computer graphics and interactive techniques community within ACM SIGGRAPH and beyond.The ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community organizes juried online exhibitions of digital arts, and collaborates on arts-related events and exhibitions at the annual SIGGRAPH and SIGGRAPH Asia conferences, as well as year-round. Our diverse, multi-generational community includes members from academic art and media programs, the professional media arts and game worlds, and scientists interested in the intersection of art and computation. We celebrate digital art history and encourage art-science partnerships at all levels. We also partner with the SIGGRAPH History Committee and ISEA on the development of digital art history archives. Our signature programs include online, juried exhibitions, the monthly SPARKS lightning talk discussion series, and our online community forums. Learn more about what we do, and how to get involved at this session.

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

Description:
Production Session
In Person
The Batman is the 19th appearance of the Caped Crusader in film, and as such, director Matt Reeves needed to find a new angle for the titular hero. The film’s thematic styling takes its cues from seventies noir crime thrillers like The Conversation, Roman Polanski’s Chinatown and Alan J. Pakula’s acclaimed Paranoia trilogy. The result is a brooding, ominous tone befitting the Gotham City setting and reflective of Reeves’ emotionally complicated version of the Batman in his early years as a crime fighter. This look and feel was the pervading influence on Wētā FX’s approach to the VFX.

Wētā FX’s work includes striking scenes in Gotham City, the Batmobile launching through flames in a chaotic car chase, and a novel approach to lensing and in-camera effects. Compositing Supervisor Beck Veitch presents the work alongside Animation Supervisor Dennis Yoo.

Their biggest and most complex scene was the Batmobile Chase sequence—the climax of the second act where Batman is chasing down Penguin in a torrential downpour. Plates shot on several different locations (a notable one being the Dunsfold Aerodrome in the UK, which is well known as the Top Gear track) were augmented with trucks and other vehicles, and the end of the sequence is entirely CG. Dennis Yoo will describe the intensive process of post-vising the action to work out timing, composition and action beats, and share his team’s fresh approach to adding torrential rain to dry sets on a tight timeline.

Practical cinematography was driven by DP Greg Fraser, who utilised things like sodium vapour and fluorescent light sources to add a malevolent, sickly feeling to the photography, and customised lenses that create interesting distortion effects in the defocused backgrounds and double imaging. Beck will explain how these in-camera effects were recreated in comp, and how she took a practical approach to lens flares that appear as caustics bouncing off water drops stuck to the camera.

Beck and Dennis also talk through the production of two major environments--the Batcave, an abandoned neo-gothic subway, and the City Hall, where the mayor’s funeral is gate-crashed by an unlucky victim.

DON'T MISS!
Wētā FX Presents The Batman
Wednesday, 10 August, 12:30-1:30 pm
Located outside Ballroom C/D

Contributors
Beck Veitch, Wētā FX
Dennis Yoo, Wētā FX
Discord: join the conversation
Recording: This session WILL NOT be recorded.
Title: Wētā FX Presents The Batman

Description:
Special Interest Group Presentation
In Person
The Berthouzoz Women in Research Event is an annual networking event organized by WiGRAPH for researchers, faculty, and students. Floraine Berthouzoz started this event as an informal gathering. After her passing in 2015, Floraine’s mentees and colleagues built upon her efforts to create an event that aims to broaden the network of women researchers and provide a friendly and personal environment where graduate students can interact with senior researchers. We will be hosting a panel of women in graphics who will share with us some of their research experiences. The event is open to all researchers, regardless of gender.

Contributors
Yingying Ren, WiGRAPH, EPFL

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
An organization’s impact is marked by the memory and artifacts it leaves behind. In 2023, ACM SIGGRAPH will celebrate its 50th conference and in an effort to document the amazing achievements of its community members, two archiving efforts have been initiated - a digital, online archive and a physical archive of publications and artifacts. These projects are co-directed by Bonnie Mitchell and Jan Searleman and involve a large community of SIGGRAPH Pioneers, community members, students, and other volunteers. This talk will showcase the ACM SIGGRAPH History online archive (https://history.SIGGRAPH.com) and the data entered so far as well as discuss the state of the physical archives. It will also illustrate the SIGGRAPH's relationship to other archives and how it is part of an international interconnected network of online new media archives.

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

Contributors
Bonnie Mitchell, ACM SIGGRAPH History Committee, Bowling Green State University
Janice Searleman, ACM SIGGRAPH History Committee, Clarkson University
Title: History: Archiving Our Past - ACM SIGGRAPH History Online Archives.

Description:
Frontiers
In Person
The history of computer graphics is dominated by the quest for photorealism. Yet esports gamers have not benefited from the results, regularly turning off all visual effects to maximize frame rate. How can the SIGGRAPH community better support the expert performance esports athletes seek? This is not an idle question: esports now rivals traditional sports in both viewership and revenue, and is already driving demand for new, high-performance displays and mice. This workshop will examine the challenges involved in finding the answers, including innovation in display, rendering and interaction.

Contributors
Benjamin Watson, North Carolina State University
Josef Spjut, NVIDIA
Byungjoo Lee, Yonsei University
Greg Ward, Dolby Laboratories
Discord: join the conversation
Title: Frontiers Workshop: The Esports Frontier: Rendering, Interaction and Display

Contact and Friction Simulation for Computer Graphics

Course
Virtual
This course covers fundamental topics on the nature of contact modeling and simulation for computer graphics. We provide mathematical details about modeling contact in rigid and soft body animations, as well as numerical methods for solving the dynamical systems. We also cover approaches for contact generation using discrete collision detection.

Contributors
Sheldon Andrews, École de Technologie Supérieure, McGill University
Kenny Erleben, University of Copenhagen
Zachary Ferguson, New York University
Discord: join the conversation


Course on Virtual Nature as a Digital Twin: Botanically Correct 3D AR and VR Optimized Low-polygon and Photogrammetry High-polygon Plant Models

Course
Virtual
Virtual nature as a digital twin and methods using GIS data in foliage brushes of botanically accurate plant models to create natural environments are covered. Two 3D plant model creation pipelines are demonstrated, one for optimized AR/VR low-polygon models and the second for high-polygon Unreal Engine 5 and RealityCapture models.

Contributors
Maria Harrington, University of Central Florida, The Harrington Lab
Chris Jones, University of Central Florida, Independent Consultant
Crissy Peters, University of Central Florida, Independent Consultant
Discord: join the conversation


Differentiable Cameras and Displays

Course
Virtual
This course provides an introduction to differentiable wave propagation approaches and describes its application to displays and cameras. Specifically, the optical components of displays and cameras are treated as differentiable layers, akin to neural network layers, that can be trained jointly with the computational blocks of an imaging/display system.

Description:
ACM SIGGRAPH Village
In Person
The double-curated exhibit will be screened and is open for a gathering of students, faculty, and industry professionals to view and discuss the projects and student works included. Sponsored by the ACM SIGGRAPH Education Committee and designed as a way for educators to share their project ideas across schools and disciplines, the Faculty Submitted Student Work Exhibit, or FSSW, is an online archive of assignment and project briefs as well as a curated video emphasizing the variety of student work and schools submitted. The annual exhibition video is a taste of the content available on the Education Committee website and this reception showcases and celebrates to the greater SIGGRAPH community the best examples of student work done for projects and assignments for the 2021-2022 school year.

During SIGGRAPH 2022, you can participate in ACM SIGGRAPH Village events, learn about the organization, and more by visiting http://village.siggraph.org.

In Person, Virtual-Livestream

A Showcase of Decima Engine in Horizon Forbidden West

We will showcase a number of features of the Decima Engine's features that power the visuals and gameplay in Horizon Forbidden West. The audience will get a behind the scenes look of some of the real-time systems that drive the rich dynamism of the world of Horizon.

AI and Physics Assisted Character Pose Authoring (c) 2022 Unity Technologies

We present a tool that allows users to quickly author character poses. Our tool leverages both machine learning and a physics engine to enable users with no artistic experience to author natural-looking poses in a few seconds.

Description:
Frontiers
In Person
Telepresence has the potential to bring billions of people into AR and VR. It is the next step in the evolution from telegraphy to telephony to videoconferencing. Just like telephony and video-conferencing, the key attribute of success will be “authenticity”: users' trust that received signals (e.g., audio for the telephone and video/audio for VC) are truly those transmitted by their friends, colleagues, or family. The challenge arises from this seeming contradiction: how do we enable authentic interactions in artificial environments? In 2019, Yaser Sheikh from Meta Reality Labs Pittsburgh gave a frontier talk introducing metric telepresence: realtime social interactions in AR/VR with avatars that look like you, move like you, and sound like you. This year, Yaser will discuss progress towards achieving metric telepresence. He will describe Meta’s approach using codec avatars — neural networks to address computer vision and computer graphics problems in signal transmission and reception of photorealistic avatars. He will also introduce the large scale systems required to train codec avatars, visually and acoustically, and the research challenges ahead to achieve metric telepresence at scale.

Contributors
Yaser Sheikh, Meta Research

Title: Frontier Talk: Metric Telepresence using Codec Avatars

How can a computer build a robot? A bottom-up introduction to computational robot co-design. Reviews (differentiable) rigid- and soft-bodied simulation and robot control methods.
